questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is brought to the pediatrician for evaluation of multiple episodes of seizures and hypoglycemia. On examination, there is growth retardation, hepatomegaly, and hypotonia. Lab workup reveals normal serum lactate, uric acid, and serum triglyceride levels. A liver biopsy demonstrates hepatocytes with large glycogen stores. Biochemical analysis reveals glycogen with short outer chains. Which of the following enzymes is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario of an infant presenting with hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and growth retardation with normal blood lactate and uric acid levels, the most likely diagnosis is Cori disease. 

Cori disease (type III glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to a deficiency of the glycogen debranching enzyme. The features of Cori disease include hypoglycemia, hepatomegaly, and hyperlipidemia but with normal blood lactate and uric acid levels. Muscle weakness and atrophy can also occur in these patients. Liver biopsy shows the accumulation of glycogen in the form of limit-dextrins (glycogen with short outer chain) in hepatocyte cytosol and the presence of fibrous septa. Cori disease can be differentiated from Von Gierke disease on the basis of:

  Von Gierke Disease Cori Disease
Deficient enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase Debranching enzyme
Hypoglycemia Present Present
Hepatomegaly Present Present
Renal disease Present (proteinuria, hypertension, renal stones) Absent
Blood lactate Elevated Normal
Blood uric acid Elevated Normal
Gluconeogenesis Impaired, since glucose-6-phosphatase is required in the final step of gluconeogenesis Intact

questions.text: You are asked to opine on the age of an adolescent boy allegedly involved in a crime. He claims to be a juvenile and pleads for a trial in the juvenile court. Based on the X-ray shown below, the likely age of the boy is:
questions.solution:
The given X-ray shows the appearance of pisiform but no fusion of base of 1st metacarpal. Therefore, the age is more than 10 years and less than 17 years. Among the given options, the age of the boy is likely to be <17 years.

The base of all metacarpals appears at 2-3 years of age and fuses at 15 -17 years of age. Since it is not fused in this case, the age is less than 17 years. If it has fused the likely age is more than 15 years.

Pisiform ossification center appears at 10-12 years of age (options C and D). Since it is present in this case, the age of the child is more than 10 years. If it had not appeared, the likely age is <12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18-19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5-6 years of age and fuses at 17-18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18.

Related Pearl: Appearance of ossification centres of carpal bones

  • Capitate – 2 months (1-3 months)
  • Hamate – 3 months (2-4 months)
  • Triquetrum – 3 years
  • Lunate, Scaphoid, trapezoid, Trapezium – 4 years in females and 5 years in males
  • Pisiform – 9 or 10 years in females and 12 years in males

questions.text: A 1-month-old male baby was brought to you with complaints of a left-sided flank mass. The mother reported that the child cries while urinating and had been treated with antibiotics for urinary tract infection. Ultrasonography was done and revealed dilation of the pelvicalyceal system, with a normal-looking distal urinary tract. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the ultrasonograph showing hydronephrosis of the affected kidney indicate a likely diagnosis of ureteropelvic junction obstruction (UPJ) associated with UTI.

Hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound; it can, however, be transient or mild and resolves on its own. Re-evaluation should be done after birth and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and in cases of failure to thrive.

If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness. It needs to be ascertained whether the other kidney is involved, the lower ureter is dilated, the bladder wall is thickened, and whether emptying of the bladder is incomplete. Based on these findings, a diagnosis can be made.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (e.g. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. The investigation of choice for UPJ obstruction is 99mTc-MercaptoAcetyl-triGlycine (MAG3) scan. Micturating cystourethrogram is the investigation of choice in vesicoureteric reflux. 99mTc-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) scan is used for assessing renal scarring.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or if there is bilateral involvement of the kidneys. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

Other options:

Option B: Vesicoureteral reflux is the second most common cause of hydronephrosis after UPJ obstruction. In vesicoureteric reflux, the valve that prevents the backflow of urine from the bladder into the ureter is defective; hence, abnormal backflow of urine occurs from the bladder into the ureter. It may also present with hydronephrosis; however, the distal ureter is also involved, unlike in this case.

Option C: Ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter, thought to result from the persistence of the membrane between the ureteral bud and urogenital sinus. Since the distal urinary tract is normal-looking in this case, this diagnosis is unlikely.

Option D: Posterior urethral valve is an obstructing membrane in the posterior male urethra as a result of abnormal in-utero development. It is the most common cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male newborns. As a result, bilateral hydronephrosis and bladder dilatation is seen, unlike the unilateral involvement in this case.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hydronephrosis

Unilateral hydronephrosis

Extramural obstruction

  • Tumor from adjacent structures, e.g., cervix, prostate, rectum, colon, or cecum
  • Retrocaval ureter
  • Aberrant renal vessels
  • Idiopathic retroperitoneal fibrosis (Ormond’s disease)

Intramural obstruction

  • Congenital PUJ obstruction - most common congenital cause
  • Congenital stenosis
  • Ureterocele
  • Ureteric stricture - iatrogenic/ inflammatory
  • Neoplasm of the ureter or bladder involving the ureteric orifice

Intraluminal obstruction

  • Renal stones - most common acquired unilateral cause
  • Sloughed papilla in papillary necrosis (especially, in patients with diabetes, analgesic abuse, or sickle cell disease)

Bilateral hydronephrosis

Congenital

  • Posterior urethral valves (associated with pulmonary hypoplasia)
  • Urethral atresia
  • PUJ obstruction

Acquired     

  • Benign prostatic hypertrophy or carcinoma of the prostate

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a history of palpitations, panic attacks, and difficulty swallowing. Examination reveals a heart rate of 110 bpm, a blood pressure of 156/100 mmHg, and a neck swelling that moves with swallowing. Labs show hypercalcemia, elevated calcitonin, and parathormone levels and an MRI shows bilateral adrenal masses. What gene is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has multiple endocrine neoplasia 2A (MEN) due to a gain of function mutation of RET proto-oncogene. 

Palpitations, panic attacks, tachycardia, hypertension with bilateral adrenal masses suggest the presence of a pheochromocytoma. Difficulty swallowing and a neck swelling that moves with swallowing along with elevated calcitonin indicated medullary carcinoma of the thyroid. Hypercalcemia and elevated PTH could reflect parathyroid hyperplasia. Pheochromocytoma, medullary carcinoma of the thyroid, and parathyroid hyperplasia is seen in MEN 2A.

MEN type 2 is classified into MEN 2A and MEN 2B. 

MEN 2A is also called Sipple syndrome and characterized by

  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia.

MEN 2B is characterized by

  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid
  • Pheochromocytoma.
  • Mucosal neuromas of lips and tongue, intestinal ganglioneuromas, marfanoid habitus, and lax joints.
  • Parathyroid hyperplasia is absent. 

Other options:

Option B: Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene lead to MEN 1, also called Wermer syndrome.  It is characterized by

  • Parathyroid hyperplasia or adenoma
  • Pancreas - endocrine tumors
  • Pituitary - the most common anterior pituitary tumor is prolactinoma

Option D: CDKN1B mutations cause MEN 4. This is characterized by clinical features similar to MEN 1.

Option A: p53 tumor suppressor gene mutations can lead to Li Fraumeni syndrome. This is an autosomal dominant hereditary cancer disorder. Patients develop multiple cancers at a young age such as sarcomas, breast cancer, brain tumors, and leukemias.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

questions.text: A 65-year old man comes with complaints of headache in the occipital region. He is known hypertensive who is on antihypertensive therapy. Thorough testing revealed no abnormality. A psychological stress test was performed which increased the blood pressure and the patient complained of a headache during the test. A rise in noradrenaline levels was also noted. The patient's medication was changed from nifedipine to cilnidipine. Which of the following calcium channels does cilnidipine block?
questions.solution:
Cilnidipine blocks both N and L-type calcium channels. 

Cilnidipine is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It blocks the L-type calcium channels in blood vessels and inhibits the contraction of blood vessels and blocks the N-type calcium channels located at the sympathetic nerve endings, inhibiting the release of norepinephrine. 

It is used in hypertension especially in patients with diabetes and albuminuria and chronic kidney disease as it has end-organ protective properties. It has shown to be useful in psychological stress and white coat phenomenon.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is brought to the OPD for a well-baby check-up. The baby has been exclusively breastfed and has received all age-appropriate immunizations.  The baby's mother was treated with antibiotics two weeks ago for typhoid infection, during which she continued to breastfeed the baby. The baby's grandmother was recently diagnosed with malignant melanoma. On examination, the anthropometry is age-appropriate and vitals are within normal limits. The mother is worried about the discoloration of the skin of the baby as shown below. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The above image shows mongolian spots or congenital dermal melanocytosis, which is a benign finding in newborns. Parents must be reassured and explained about the condition.

Mongolian spots are benign blue or slate-grey macular lesions, with clearly defined margins, that appear over the presacral region (most common), posterior thighs, legs, back, and forearms. These spots occur due to the presence of melanin-containing melanocytes in the dermis, which is arrested during the migration from neural crest cells to the epidermis. They are non-tender and do not rapidly change in colour or size. They do not require any treatment and fade by age 1-6 years of age.

Congenital dermal melanocytosis is a clinical diagnosis. Since this baby has a classic presentation of mongolian spots, skin biopsy is not required for diagnosis. Topical steroid application has no role in the treatment of dermal melanocytosis.

Grey-baby syndrome is caused by the increased levels of chloramphenicol in the baby, when a breastfeeding mother is treated with chloramphenicol. It is characterized by abdominal distension, flaccidity, cyanosis appearing as ashen-gray color, circulatory collapse and death. This baby has stable vital signs and the bluish-gray discoloration is limited to the buttocks, ruling out gray-baby syndrome. This baby's mother must have received alternate antibiotics for typhoid. Hence, serum chlroramphenicol levels need not be measured.

Related Pearl: Benign findings in a newborn

1. Erythema toxicum – small, white papules on an erythematous base that usually present on the face, trunk, and extremities. They contain eosinophils and may persist for a week. 

 

2. Mongolian spots – Slate-blue, demarcated areas of pigmentation seen over the buttocks and back. This is also called dermal melanocytosis. 

 

3. Pustular melanosis – Benign lesions seen predominantly in black neonates, contains neutrophils, and is present at birth as vesiculopustular eruption around the chin, neck, back, extremities, palms and soles.

 

4. Sebaceous Hyperplasia - White-Yellow papules on nose of a newborn due to hyperplastic sebaceous glands

 

5. Milia - Pearly opalescent white, epidermal inclusion cysts usually over the face.

 

6. Epstein Pearls - nests of epithelial cells, that appear as whitish/yellowish spots on hard palate. Usually, resolve by 3 months.

 

7. Cutis Marmorata - Transient lacy reticular vascular pattern of skin caused due to exaggerated physiologic vasomotor response on exposure to low environmental temperature.

 

8. Sucking Blisters - Solitary or scattered superficial bullae present at birth on the upper limbs of infants, which are caused by vigorous sucking on the affected part in-utero.

 

9. Salmon patch or naevus simplex - Small, ill-defined, pink-coloured macules commonly seen over glabella, eyelids, upper lip, and nuchal area, which develop due to vascular ectasia.

 

10. Harlequin colour change - A transient, well-demarcated colour change, with one half of the body displaying erythema and the other half pallor, usually occurring between two and five days of age.

 

11. Vaginal bleeding in the newborn at 2–3 days of age and enlargement and secretion of the breasts in both sexes.

12. Hymenal tags

13. Physiological phimosis

14. Conjunctival hemorrhage

15. Peeling of skin (especially in post terms)

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy presents with an erythematous rash with central clearing on the back of his right thigh as shown in the image below. No other skin rashes are noted, and the rest of the examination is normal. The child had recently been on vacation with his family in Oregon, USA, and had gone hiking during the last week of his stay there. The parents recall the child developed fever, headache, and body pain immediately after returning from the hike, which resolved in two days. Which of the following diseases can also be transmitted by the vector causing the above disease?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a target sign rash or bull's eye rash which is pathognomonic of Lyme’s disease, caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, which is transmitted via the bite of Ixodes ticks (hard ticks). Ehrlichiosis is also transmitted via the bite of a hard tick vector. 

Co-infection may be a potential problem for humans, because the Ixodes ticks often carry and transmit other pathogens, as well. Other infections that are transmitted by hard ticks are-

  • Babesia
  • Anaplasma
  • Spotted fever rickettsial infections- RMSF, Indian tick typhus, Boutonneuse fever, Kenyan tick typhus.
  • Francisella tularensis
  • Viruses like Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF), Severe fever with thrombocytopenia syndrome (SFTS), Coltivirus, Kyasanur forest disease (KFD), tick borne encephalitis (TBE), Omsk hemorrhagic fever.

In humans, Ehrlichiosis presents with fever and flu-like symptoms. Leukopenia and thrombocytopenia are seen. The bacteria have affinity to blood cells and form mulberry like structures in phagocytes called morula formation, which is seen on Giemsa stained blood film. 

Other options :

  • Q fever is transmitted to humans via the inhalation of aerosols contaminated with Coxiella or unpasteurized milk or percutaneous through handling of infected animal products. 
  • Leptospirosis is typically transmitted via mucous membrane or abraded skin exposure to rat urine contaminated water. 
  • Eastern equine encephalitis is transmitted by mosquito bites.

questions.text: A 14-year-old male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of a large rash-like lesion on the back and left shoulder. He noticed it for the first time 3 months ago during his swimming practice and it has become darker since then. There is no pain or itching associated with the lesion.  His pulse rate is 67, his BP is 110/70 mm of Hg, and his temperature is 98.3F. On examination, there is a 15x20 cm irregular, hyperpigmented patch over the left shoulder and back. There is excessive hair growth over the lesion. The image of the physical examination findings is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Becker's Naevus.

Becker's naevus is an epidermal melanocytic naevus. It is classically seen as a hyperpigmented, brownish patch over the scapular area on the back, shoulders, outer arms, and chest. It is usually associated with hypertrichosis and sometimes with acne.

It is caused due to an aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis. It has an onset around adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens.

Other options:

Option A- Mongolian spots are slate blue areas in the lumbosacral region that spontaneously regresses before puberty, making it unlikely in this case.

Option B- Naevus of Ito is a unilateral hyperpigmentation in the acromioclavicular distribution. It is unlikely in this case as it is not known to have hypertrichosis or acne.

Option C- Pityriasis rosea is characterized by typical skin eruptions consisting of macules with a collarette scale. It is seen in a characteristic "Christmas tree pattern" over the back, and it is preceded by an oval herald patch two weeks before the onset of the rash. Although it is also seen in young adults, it is unlikely in this patient due to the absence of typical history and presentation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with lung adenocarcinoma comes for her chemotherapy treatment. She has had multiple complaints of nausea and vomiting during her previous treatment visits. In order to prevent this, the physician prescribes a combination of a 5HT3 receptor antagonist and netupitant along with dexamethasone. Which of the following 5HT3 receptor antagonists is used in this combination to prevent chemotherapy-induced emesis and vomiting?
questions.solution:
Palonosetron is used with netupitant in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting. 

Palonosetron is a 5HT3 receptor antagonist that blocks serotonin in vagal terminals and centrally in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ). It has a higher receptor affinity as compared to the first-generation 5HT3 antagonists making it more potent. It is also useful in delayed emesis associated with chemotherapy due to its long half-life. 

It is used in combination with netupitant in acute and delayed nausea and vomiting. Netupitant is an NK1 receptor antagonist. It augments the effects of palonosetron. This combination is particularly anti-emetogenic when given along with dexamethasone.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with a history of recurrent abscesses secondary to staphylococcus aureus infection. Primary immunodeficiency was suspected. The nitro-blue tetrazolium test was performed which was negative. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this patient with a suspected primary immunodeficiency, repeated infections with Staphylococcus aureus (catalase-positive organisms) and a negative nitro-blue tetrazolium test is suggestive of Chronic Granulomatous Disease (CGD).

It is due to a defect in NADPH oxidase, the enzyme responsible for the generation of superoxide during the respiratory burst. Defective inherent production of reactive oxygen species leads to increased susceptibility to life-threatening infections- pulmonary, cutaneous, lymphatic, hepatic, and osteomyelitis. These patients are susceptible to catalase-positive organisms like Staphylococcus and Coliforms.

Nitro blue tetrazolium test can be used for the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease. The leukocytes fail to reduce nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) during phagocytosis in chronic granulomatous disease.

Other options: 

Option A: Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is a disorder of T-lymphocytes (cellular immunity) and is characterized by the triad of recurrent severe infections, thrombocytopenia, and eczema. This patient does not present with eczema or symptoms of thrombocytopenia like petechiae, recurrent gum bleeds or nose bleeds.

Option C: Chediak- Higashi syndrome is a primary immunodeficiency due to a disorder of the phagolysosome function of leukocytes, leading to delayed microbial clearance. In addition, there is a disorder of melanin (albinism), nerve defects, and bleeding disorders.

Option D: Severe combined immunodeficiency is a primary immunodeficiency with a disorder of both cellular and humoral immunity. Persons with SCID are susceptible to recurrent severe infections caused by a wide variety of pathogens and usually do not survive beyond the first year of life without a stem cell transplant.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old male comes to the OPD with complaints of nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and malaise for the past week. His wife noticed a yellowish discoloration of sclera and skin for the past 3 days. The symptoms started on returning home after attending a village fair. He works as a janitor at a nursing home and upon questioning, he says that he pricked himself with a needle two weeks ago while transferring medical waste. He has no other significant past history. Pallor and icterus are present. On palpating the abdomen, there is tender hepatomegaly. Liver function test results are given below. In addition to this, which among the following list of investigations are best suited in this case?

Liver function test results-

Total Bilirubin 5.8 mg/dl
ALT  1860 U/L
AST  1287 U/L
GGT 478 U/L
ALP 367 U/L

 

List of investigations-

  1. Anti-HAV (IgM)
  2. HBsAg
  3. Anti-HBc (IgM)
  4. Anti-HBe (IgM)
  5. Anti-HCV (IgM) & HCV RNA 
  6. Anti-HEV (IgM and IgG)
questions.solution:
Anti-HAV (IgM); HBsAg, anti-HBc (IgM); anti-HCV (IgM), HCV RNA; and anti-HEV (IgM and IgG) are the most appropriate investigations for the preliminary examination of a case of suspected acute viral hepatitis. 

The history, clinical presentation, and laboratory results in this clinical vignette are all suggestive of acute viral hepatitis -

Clinical presentation of acute viral hepatitis is non-specific and includes nausea, vomiting, fever, myalgia, fatigue, etc associated with jaundice. 

Physical examination may reveal icterus and right upper quadrant tenderness suggesting hepatomegaly. 

Laboratory investigation suggests acute hepatocellular injury with a sharp rise in ALT and AST (usually over 1000 IU/L) with ALT>AST, hyperbilirubinemia, with elevated GGT and ALP. Additionally, the viral cause of hepatitis may be ascertained using the following serological markers-

  • Hepatitis A (The most common cause of acute hepatitis in children): IgM anti-HAV antibody 
  • Hepatitis B: HBsAg (first marker to rise) and IgM anti-HBc (most reliable marker of acute infection)
  • Hepatitis C: IgM Anti-HCV and HCV RNA
  • Hepatitis E (The most common cause of acute viral hepatitis in adults): IgM and IgG anti-HEV.

Note: IgM Anti-HDV antibody is not assessed during the investigation of acute hepatitis since it can only occur as a co-infection or super-infection with hepatitis B. Additionally, anti-HDV only appears in the blood 30-40 days after symptom onset. 

Note: The history suggests a possibility of feco-oral transmission, implicating hepatitis A and hepatitis E (Patient attending the village fair) and parenteral transmission, implicating hepatitis B and hepatitis C (accidental needle prick). Since the clinical symptoms of acute viral hepatitis are non-specific for the most part, the detection has to be serological. Hepatitis A and E are the most common cause of acute hepatitis in children and adults respectively, and therefore should be evaluated for. Additionally, Option D is the best option because it assesses for IgM Anti-HBc which is the most reliable marker of acute infection with hepatitis B.

questions.text: A 40-year-old nurse working in the pulmonary department presented with a productive cough and evening rise in temperature for 3 weeks duration. A chest X-ray is done and it shows cavities in the upper lobe. The clinician suspects pulmonary TB and orders a sputum smear examination on two samples which turn out to be negative. He further advises CB-NAAT which reveals Mycobacterium presence but is indeterminate on Rifampicin resistance. What should be done next as per the recent NTEP guidelines?

choices.text: Start treatment as drug sensitive TB and continue Intensive phase for 3 months
Repeat CB-NAAT testing to ascertain drug resistance before initiating treatment
Consider taking fresh sample and test it using line probe assay to detect resistance
Start treatment with MDR TB regimen using oral drugs only for 18 months

questions.solution:
As per the NTEP guidelines, repeat CB-NAAT testing to ascertain drug resistance, needs to be carried out if the first sample tested is Rif indeterminate/inconclusive.

The given case with the typical symptoms of evening rise of temperature and productive cough of more than 2 weeks duration with chest x-ray showing upper lobe cavities prompts a diagnosis of pulmonary tuberculosis. The initial diagnosis of pulmonary TB is done with sputum smear examination and chest radiography. In this case, despite 2 negative sputum samples, a chest X-ray is suggestive of tuberculosis. Hence CB-NAAT was performed. 

In cases of high clinical suspicion, Smear is negative but CXR findings are suggestive, or in people with HIV, a CB-NAAT is done. Cartridge-based nucleic acid amplification (CBNAAT) detects the presence of Mycobacterium DNA along with resistance against Rifampicin within 2 hours. It analyses sputum or any other biological specimen (except blood and blood-contaminated specimens) using real-time PCR technology

If Rifampicin resistance is absent, it is treated as drug-sensitive TB. If Rifampicin resistance is present, it is treated as drug-resistant TB. 

However, if the sample turns out to be intermediate/inconclusive, CB-NAAT is repeated using 2nd sample.

  • If the 2nd sample turns out to be positive for Rifampicin resistance, the patient is treated as Rifampicin resistant
  • If the 2nd sample turns out to be negative for Rifampicin resistance, the patient is treated as drug-sensitive
  • If the 2nd sample also turns out to be indeterminate, a fresh sample is taken for Line probe assay or liquid culture, to ascertain drug resistance.

A positive smear examination irrespective of CXR findings is diagnosed as microbiologically confirmed TB and started on ATT. Drug sensitivity is done for all new cases due to increasing resistance. Once these drug sensitivity results are available, treatment can be modified, if resistance is found.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic algorithm for Pulmonary TB – National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) 2020 Guidelines

Any case of presumptive pulmonary TB should undergo sputum examination + chest X-ray + CB-NAAT

  • If sputum and chest X-ray normal: rule out TB and refer
  • If sputum is positive and CB NAAT is positive: microbiologically confirmed case of TB

The following protocol is used for CB-NAAT testing:

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

questions.text: A 17-year-old female presents with severe cramping in her legs while exercising in the gym. She has been experiencing these symptoms for the past few months. On examination, radial pulse is 88 beats/min, and distal pulses of the lower limb are barely palpable. Blood pressure is 144/88 mmHg in the right arm and 108/70 mmHg in the right leg. The obtained chest x-ray image is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and chest x-ray showing notching of ribs strongly point towards the diagnosis of coarctation of the aorta. 

Coarctation of the aorta is a congenital heart defect characterized by the narrowing of the thoracic aorta near the insertion of the ductus arteriosus. According to the site of constriction, it is classified into the following types:

  • Preductal: constriction proximal to the ductus arteriosus (infantile type)
  • Postductal: constriction distal to the ductus arteriosus (adult type)

Clinical presentation of coarctation of the aorta depends on the extent of constriction and age at the presentation:

  • Infants with coarctation of the aorta may present with tachypnea, lethargy, failure to thrive, or overt congestive heart failure. Clinical signs classically worsen after the closure of ductus arteriosus.
  • Adults may present with non-specific symptoms, such as headaches and nose bleeds, or claudication of the lower limbs, which is experienced as cramping pain that increases on exertion.

Coarctation of the aorta is associated with the bicuspid aortic valve, berry aneurysm, and Turner syndrome.

Physical examination findings:

  • Bounding upper limb pulses (radial, carotid) and weak lower limb pulses (femoral, popliteal, posterior tibial, and dorsalis pedis)
  • Increased radio-femoral delay
  • Hypertension in upper limbs and increased difference in blood pressure between upper and lower limbs
  • Continuous like murmur (due to collaterals)
  • Systolic ejection click and systolic ejection murmur in the left upper sternal border (due to bicuspid aortic valve)

Radiologic findings on chest x-ray:

  • Figure 3 sign - It is pathognomonic of coarctation of the aorta. It occurs due to the indentation of the aorta at the site of coarctation and pre- and post-stenotic dilatation along the left para-mediastinum.
  • Notching of ribs - This occurs due to rib erosion by dilated collateral vessels.
  • Dilated left subclavian artery and dilated ascending aorta

It can be diagnosed using x-ray, CT or MRI, or cardiac catheterization. It is definitively managed surgically or with balloon dilation. 

The figure of 3 sign is shown in the image below. 

Other options:

Option A- Total anomalous pulmonary venous return is a clinical entity in which the pulmonary veins fail to enter the left atrium and instead drain into the right atrium or its systemic venous tributaries. It is classified into 4 types: supra-cardiac, cardiac, infracardiac, and mixed types. On chest radiography, the supra-cardiac type shows a characteristic snowman or figure of 8 appearance.

Option B- Takayasu arteritis is a granulomatous vasculitis involving the aorta and the pulmonary arteries, resulting in varying degrees of stenosis, occlusion, or dilatation. It can result in diminished or absent pulses, limb claudications, hypertension due to renal artery stenosis. Chest radiograph may reveal oligemic lung fields if pulmonary artery involvement occurs.

Option C- Ebstein anomaly is characterized by an abnormal tricuspid valve that is displaced downwards into the right ventricle. Hence, a part of the right ventricle is now located above the tricuspid valve. This is called atrialization of the ventricle. There can be associated tricuspid regurgitation with or without stenosis. Chest x-ray findings depend on the degree to which the tricuspid valve is displaced downwards. There is usually an enlarged right atrium, resulting in severe right-sided cardiomegaly, which gives a box-shaped heart appearance.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is brought for evaluation of repeated lung infections. The bronchial fluid samples show gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a bluish-green pigment. He also has been experiencing foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools. What is the mode of inheritance of the condition that the child is most likely to have?
questions.solution:
Repeated lung infections and steatorrhea (foul-smelling diarrhea with pale, floating stools) suggest a diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. It has an autosomal recessive inheritance pattern. Gram-negative, oxidase-positive bacteria that produce a blue-green pigment indicate infection with Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is commonly seen in this condition. 

Cystic fibrosis is an inherited disorder due to a mutation in the cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene located on chromosome 7 (7q31.2). It leads to abnormal transport of chloride and bicarbonate ions in the lungs, gastrointestinal tract, pancreas, and reproductive tract. 

  • Lungs - Abnormal CFTR leads to sticky viscous mucus with abnormal mucociliary clearance leading to obstruction and recurrent respiratory infections. 
  • Pancreas - The viscous secretions block the pancreatic ducts impairing the flow of digestive enzymes. This leads to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency, causing fat malabsorption and the resultant steatorrhea. 
  • Reproductive tract - More than 95% of men are infertile, with absent vas deferens. Women have tenacious cervical mucus but are not always infertile. 

The sweat chloride test is used to confirm the diagnosis of cystic fibrosis. Sweat ducts with normal CFTR reabsorb the chloride from the primary sweat secretion. Mutated CFTR reduces this uptake, increasing chloride levels in sweat. A sweat chloride level of >60 mmol/L is diagnostic.

Other pathogens commonly causing infections in cystic fibrosis include Staphylococcus aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Burkholderia cepacia.

questions.text:
A child born in March 2019 at the district hospital is brought to you by his mother. She states that he was given all vaccines till 1 year of age but she did not take him for vaccination since April 2020- till now due to lockdown. She is however apprehensive of her child's health and wants to immunize him. Which of the following vaccines can be given to the child now?
  1. DPT booster-1
  2. Measles 2nd dose and Vitamin A
  3. OPV booster-1
  4. JE 2nd dose

choices.text: Vaccination needs to restart since there has been a gap of 1 year in booster doses

questions.solution:
In this case of drop-out vaccination (started vaccination but did not complete it), all 4 mentioned vaccines can be given.

Catch-up vaccination involves the administration of vaccines in children who have not been immunized at all (left-outs) or for children who took vaccines, but couldn't complete the course(dropouts). Efforts should be made to ensure that all vaccines are given at the recommended ages, or closer to it. However, certain vaccines have an age limit till which they can be given. This is because the child develops immunity against a few diseases or is no longer vulnerable. 

BCG can only be given up to 1 year of age, according to the National Immunisation Schedule. 

Please note that BCG can be given up to 5 years of age, as part of the catch-up immunization schedule which is by the Indian Academy of Paediatrics and that is not followed in government setups.

OPV can be given till 5 years of age.

Measles can be given till 5 years of age.

DPT can be given until 7 years of age (with booster doses).

Only the above-mentioned vaccines have upper age limits. 

For pentavalent, IPV, PCV, and Rotavirus vaccines, if at least one dose is given before one year of age, then remaining doses can be administered and the schedule must be completed irrespective of the age of the child. If the first dose is not administered before one year of age, then these vaccines cannot be administered to the child under UIP.

questions.text: A 24-year old female G1P0L0 at 12 weeks of gestation complains of burning micturition, vaginal pruritus, and increased frequency of urination. On examination, her vitals are stable. There is no suprapubic or costovertebral angle tenderness. On per vaginal examination, there is redness of the cervix. Urine analysis is positive for leukocyte esterase but negative on Gram staining. Cervical swab Gram staining also does not show any organisms. Which of the following is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Chlamydial cervicitis and is treated with azithromycin in pregnant women.

Chlamydia trachomatis is a gram-negative obligate intracellular bacteria and is a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. 

Smears prepared from urethral and cervical secretions are used for diagnosis. As these organisms lack muramic acid in the cell wall, they do not stain well on gram staining. Diagnosis can be made through PCR (gold standard), fluorescent antibody stain, or Giemsa stain. NAATs are the most sensitive tests for these specimens and therefore are recommended for detecting C. trachomatis infection.

Chlamydia trachomatis infection is most often asymptomatic but may present as urethritis, cervicitis, vulvovaginitis, and pelvic inflammatory disease in women. Chlamydial infection in pregnancy can lead to abortion, intrauterine growth restriction, and pre-term labor. Chlamydial infections can be transmitted to the baby during birth causing conjunctivitis, nasopharyngitis, otitis media, and pneumonia.

Treatment with azithromycin (1 g orally single dose) or doxycycline (100 mg BD for 7 days) is advised both to the patient and her sexual partner. In pregnant women like this patient, doxycycline is contraindicated due to teratogenicity. Other drugs which can be used safely in pregnant women with chlamydia include erythromycin and amoxicillin. 

Ceftriaxone (500 mg IM single dose) is added empirically when there is a suspicion of gonococcal infection. It presents with purulent white discharge. In gonococcal cervicitis, gram staining of cervical swabs shows gram-negative diplococci.

questions.text:
A 64-year-old male patient who is being treated for diabetic ketoacidosis suddenly becomes hypotensive. His pulse rate is thready and rapid with BP 88/54 mm Hg. An electrocardiogram is obtained, and laboratory tests are given below. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

Blood glucose- 220 mg/dl
Sodium (Na+) - 137 mEq/L; Potassium (K+) - 2.5 mEq/L
Calcium (Ca2+) - 8.5 mg/L; Magnesium (Mg2+) -  1 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given ECG depicts torsades de pointes which is a type of polymorphic ventricular tachycardia. The most appropriate management for this patient would be IV magnesium sulfate infusion. 

Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia is characterized by variable QRS morphologies, meaning each QRS complex looks different from another, as they arise from different ventricular sites. Torsades de pointes means “twisting of the points,” as it appears as though the QRS axis is twisting around the baseline. 

These patients usually present with palpitations, dizziness, or syncope. The laboratory results may reveal the underlying cause such as hypomagnesemia and hypokalemia.

QT interval prolongation (caused due to a delay in repolarization of the ventricles) is a predisposing factor for torsades de pointes. It can be caused due to:

Inherited QT prolongation syndromes:

  • Jervell and Lange Neilson syndrome
  • Ramano-Ward syndrome.

Acquired causes:

  • Drugs like quinidine, procainamide, disopyramide, and dofetilide
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute ischemia or infarction.

The drug of choice for the management of torsades de pointes is IV magnesium sulfate infusion. It acts by suppressing early after-depolarizations that are responsible for arrhythmia, by preventing the entry of calcium into the cell. Other measures include discontinuation of the offending drug, correction of underlying electrolyte abnormalities, pH, and hypoxia. Definitive treatment includes electrical pacing.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male from a hilly area presented to the casualty with dyspnea. On examination, he had a neck swelling which moved with deglutition but with no visible lower border. There was an associated plethora of the face which was increased by overhead abduction of both arms. Chest radiograph revealed a widened mediastinum. During surgery to remove the swelling, the marked structure was found visibly compressed. What is the usual embryological origin of the marked structure?

choices.text: Right anterior cardinal vein and right common cardinal vein
Left anterior cardinal vein and left common cardinal vein
Left posterior cardinal vein and right common cardinal vein
Right posterior cardinal vein and left common cardinal vein

questions.solution:
The marked structure shows superior vena cava(SVC) formed by the joining of the brachiocephalic vein. The symptoms described are likely due to compression of the SVC by a retrosternal goiter giving rise to Superior vena cava syndrome.

The formation of the vena cava system begins with the formation of anastomoses between the right and left venous channels. Formation of the major veins takes place as follows: 

  • The proximal part of the right anterior cardinal vein along with the right common cardinal vein form the superior vena cava
  • The distal part of the right anterior cardinal vein between the junction with the subclavian vein and the junction with the transverse anastomosis becomes the right brachiocephalic vein
  • The distal part of the left anterior cardinal vein and the transverse anastomosis becomes the left brachiocephalic vein 
  • The most cranial part of both the anterior cardinal veins above its junction with the subclavian vein become the internal jugular vein

 

Anomalous development of SVC may result in the formation of SVC on the left side as well. It occurs if the regression of the left anterior and common cardinal vein is absent. It drains into the right atrium and may be associated with absent or small right (normal) SVC - Double SVC

Superior vena cava syndrome occurs due to compression of SVC in the thorax by malignant tumors, enlarging lymph nodes, mediastinal fibrosis, thyromegaly.

In this case, a neck swelling which moves with deglutition is likely the thyroid gland. A history of belonging to iodine-deficient hilly areas points to an iodine-deficient goiter. Large goiters may extend into the thorax behind the sternum, and causing an impalpable lower border. It may compress upon the mediastinal structures as in this case. 

Clinical features occur due to compression of the trachea(dyspnea) or SVC (edema and cyanosis of the face). The enlarged thyroid compresses the thoracic inlet and puts pressure on venous system. This can be aggravated by overhead abduction of both arms (Pemberton sign), causing an increase in the facial plethora.

CXR shows widened mediastinum(image above). Treatment involves the removal of obstruction on SVC and treating the cause.

questions.text: A 36-year old woman P1L1, comes to the gynecologist for contraceptive advice. She mentions multiple times that her work is highly stressful with no clear timings, that it includes long hours of standing, and that she smokes heavily. She informs that she wishes to conceive in the future and emphasizes that this is important to her. She has regular cycles but complains of heavy menstrual bleeding with dysmenorrhea lasting for 5-6 days every cycle. Which of the following contraceptive methods is the best suited for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most suitable contraceptive for this woman is Norplant.

Norplant is a subdermal implant of progesterone aimed at a slow, sustained release, long-acting effect, and reduced side effects. The implants suppress ovulation in 50% but the main action is suppressing endometrium. 

The implants can be inserted on the first day of the menstrual cycle, within 5 days of abortion, and 3 weeks after the delivery. The woman needs to use barrier contraception or abstain in the first 7 days post-insertion.

Advantages of implants:

  • They are long-acting with sustained effect—compliance is good
  • Coital-independent with no ‘nuisance’ of daily oral or frequent injections
  • Pregnancy rate—varies between 0.2 and 1.3 per 100 woman years

Disadvantages of implants:

  • Breakthrough bleeding, irregular cycles, amenorrhoea occur as with other progestogenic contraceptives
  • Ectopic pregnancy is reported in 1.3%
  • A local infection may occur
  • Requires insertion and removal with nonbiodegradable capsules, which are however minor surgical procedures

Other options:

  • This patient is above 35 years and is a heavy smoker, both of which put her at risk of thromboembolism. Combined oral contraceptive pills are contraindicated in this patient as they contain estrogen, which increases the risk of thromboembolic events.
  • Theoretically, a progestin-only pill can be used in this patient. However given her busy and stressful work schedule, she may not be compliant with daily oral medications. Thus long-acting implants are best suited.
  • This patient has a history of heavy menstrual bleeding which is a contraindication to Copper - T intra-uterine devices (IUDs)

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman comes for a follow-up, 1 week after her first child was born. Her husband reports that his wife appears uninterested in taking care of the baby, has sudden crying outbursts and seems sad for no reason for the last 2 days. Her sleep is disturbed and she feels fatigued. She is able to carry out the daily chores and enjoys watching television like before. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has mild depressive symptoms within the first week of delivery. So the most likely diagnosis is postpartum blues.

Postpartum blues, also called maternity blues, typically develop within one week of delivery, usually on the fourth or fifth postpartum day. The affected mothers are emotionally labile and the symptoms include changes in mood, sudden crying outbursts, and a lack of interest in the baby. They may also have insomnia, anxiety, poor concentration, and irritability.

These feelings have been ascribed to rapid changes in women's hormonal levels, the stress of childbirth, and the awareness of the increased responsibility that motherhood brings. This usually resolves spontaneously within 10-14 days. 

Management involves reassurance, education, and support. The patient must be followed-up and assessed for the possible development of a major depressive disorder.

Other options:

Option B: Symptoms should persist for >2 weeks to make the diagnosis of post-partum depression. A minimum of 5 symptoms of major depressive disorder i.e. impaired sleep, interest, guilt, energy, concentration, appetite, psychomotor activity, and suicidal ideation must be present. This patient is able to do her daily chores, enjoys watching TV, has a good appetite, and does not have guilt or suicidal ideation. Although this patient has disturbed sleep and fatigue, these are common physiological postpartum findings.

Option C: Post-partum psychosis is a psychiatric emergency and usually has a mean time of onset is 2-3 weeks postpartum. The predominant symptoms are hallucinations, delusions, suicidal thoughts, and thoughts of harming the baby. The onset of psychotic symptoms is usually preceded by signs such as insomnia, restlessness, labile mood, and agitation. Lithium, often in combina­tion with an antidepressant, is the treatment of choice.

Option D: Episodes of delirium in the postpartum period are characterized by a fluctuating level of awareness or attention. In this patient, there is no altered sense of awareness.

Note:  Zuranolone is the first-ever oral drug to be approved specifically for the treatment of postpartum depression. It is a neuroactive steroid that enhances the action of GABA in the brain and regulates mood.
